trial_identification.studytitle: A targeted community program of vitamin D treatment to reduce hospital admissions for falls, fractures and other disorders
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A randomised controlled placebo-controlled study to evaluate the effects of vitamin D treatment on reducing hospital admissions for falls, fractures and other disorders in elderly women

interventions.interventions: 150,000 IU vitamin D (cholecalciferol) taken orally as 3 capsules at three clinic visits three months apart; lifestyle advice on physical activity and calcium intake given at baseline through an information sheet administered by trained research assistants
interventions.comparator: Three identical placebo capsules made of lactose taken orally at three clinic visits three months apart; lifestyle advice on physical activity and calcium intake given at baseline through an information sheet administered by trained research assistants

primaryOutcome.outcome: Falls events in general as recorded by subjects on a condition and medication logbook and reviewed at clinic visits three months apart by trained research assistants
Falls events (as recorded by subjects on a condition and medication logbook and reviewed at clinic visits three months apart by trained research assistants) in winter/spring

Falls events (as recorded by subjects on a condition and medication logbook and reviewed at clinic visits three months apart by trained research assistants) in those with baseline serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D (25(OH)D) levels less than 60 nmol/L.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D (25OHD) levels as assessed by the Liquid Chromatography Tandem Mass Spectrometry (LC-MS/MS) method
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At 3, 6 and 9 months after intervention commencement

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Adverse events including vascular diseases, cancer, hypocalcaemia and renal calculus as recorded by subjects on a condition and medication logbook and reviewed at clinic visits three months apart by trained research assistants
Direct costs of the intervention and the costs of falls related adverse events
Mobility function as assessed by the Timed Up and Go test and hand grip strength as assessed by a hand dynamometer
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At 3, 6 and 9 months after intervention commencement

trial_design.concealment: Subjects numbers were allocated by the pharmacy who has no contact with study participants

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Bone and Calcium Research Group, School of Medicine and Pharmacology, University of Western Australia, Department of Endocrinology and Diabetes, 1st Floor C Block, Sir Charles Gairdner Hospital, Hospital Ave, Nedlands WA 6009

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This is a nine-month randomised controlled study to evaluate the effects of vitamin D 150,000 IU per three months on risk of falling, serum vitamin D levels, mobility function and muscle strength in women aged 70 years and over at a community setting.

ethicscommitee.ethicname: Sir Charles Gairdner Hospital Human Research Ethics Committee
ethicscommitee.ethicaddress: 1st Floor E Block, Sir Charles Gairdner Hospital, Hospital Ave, Nedlands, WA 6009

contact.name: Professor Richard L Prince
